heading: 1.1 What is demography and why is it important?
text: Discussion questionsBirthDeathMigrationTimeSpaceStructure

heading: Definitions of demography
text: ‚Äú‚Ä¶scientific study human populations primarily respect size, structure development; takes account quantitative aspects general characteristics.6The study human populations relation changes brought interplay births, deaths, migration.7‚Äú‚Ä¶study human populations ‚Äì size, composition distribution across space ‚Äì process populations change.8Emphasis added.

heading: Okay so what‚Äôs a ‚Äúpopulation‚Äù then?
text:
statistians: collection itemsFor demographers:collection persons‚Ä¶meet certain criteriaalive specified point time‚Ä¶
Non-human biologists demography, .Dr.¬†Hal Caswell, Professor Mathematical Demography University Amsterdam: https://www.uva.nl/en/profile/c//h.caswell/h.caswell.htmlWrote influential book matrix population models (aka‚Ä¶ demography)‚Äúresearch focuses population models, usually based matrices, plants, [non-human] animals, humans. interested stochastic processes demography‚Ä¶‚Äù‚Äì Hal Caswell (emphasis)Collection: People‚Ä¶Criteria: living King County, Washington‚Ä¶Specified point time: April 1, 2019Also demographers:Now can see population changes, case time‚Ä¶King County population grew 28% 14 years.

heading: 1.2 The balancing equation of population change
text: Consider observation period length \(T\)now, arbitrarily set period‚Äôs starting point time \(t = 0\)\(\begin{align} N(T) &= \textsf{ (Ending population size time } T \textsf{)} \\  &+ N(0) \textsf{ (Starting population size time } 0 \textsf{)} \\  &+ B[0,T] \textsf{ (Number births start end)} \\  &- D[0,T] \textsf{ (Number deaths start end)} \\  &+ [0,T] \textsf{ (Number -migrations start end)} \\  &- O[0,T] \textsf{ (Number -migrations start end)} \\ \end{align}\)

heading: Balancing equation as flows and stocks
text: Boxes represent states individuals population can inArrows represent flow individuals one state anotherBalancing equation stock flow chart

heading: 1.3 The structure of demographic rates
Person-periods: A central concept in demography
From lifelines to event counts and person-periods
text:
Basic factsConsider group (population?) individuals denoted \(G\)\(A_i\): Beginning lifeline individual \(\G\)\(B_i\): End individual \(\)‚Äôs lifeline\(\theta_{ij}\): \(j\)th among \(N_i\) occurrences lifeline individual \(\)\(T_i = B_i - A_i\): length individual \(\)‚Äôs lifelineRate group defined entire lifelines:\[\textsf{Rate}_G = \frac{\sum_{\G} N_i}
{\sum_{\G} T_i}\]toy example illustrate exposure rates work‚Ä¶KEY CONCEPTExposure rates weight individuals denominator number person-periods exposed risk event.

heading: 1.4 Period rates and person-years (er‚Ä¶ person-periods)
1.5 Principal period rates in demography
1.6.1 Crude growth rate
text: Recall balancing equation:\[N(T) = N[0] + B[0,T] - D[0,T] + [0,T] - O[0,T]\]\(N(T) - N(0)\) (period change population count)Step 1: Subtract \(N(0)\) sidesPutting together substituting principal period rates:

heading: 1.6.2 Instantaneous growth rate
1.6.3 Mean annualized growth rate
1.6.4 Doubling time
text: population doubles, \(\text{ln}\left[[N(T)/N(0)\right] = \text{ln}[2] \approx 0.693\)Assuming constant growth \(r^*\) plugging 0.693 Equation (1.4):\[\textsf{Doubling time} \approx \frac{0.693}{r^*}\]

heading: 1.6.5 Comparison of crude growth rate and mean annualized growth rate
text: Note start end population belowYet person years (areas curves) definitely aren‚Äôt !Fig 1.2 PHG cuz got lazyKEY CONCEPTWith exceptions, crude growth rate mean annualized growth rate equal unless constant growth rate \(r^*\).

heading: 1.7 Estimating period person-periods
text: Often, don‚Äôt access data individual lifelinesConsequence: estimate person-periods calculate rates

heading: Method 1: Assume constant growth rate \(r\) during the period
Method 2: Use mid-period population
text:
Often, demographers don‚Äôt start ending populationInstead, mid-period population countExample: Decennial U.S. CensusMid-period population estimate works best within-period growth linear
two scenarios linear population change.black dot shows within-period population = \(PY[0,1]\)Notice ‚Äôs mid-periodNote -estimate one half year balanced -estimate half yearBelow scenarios exponentially changing populations.Notice mid-period population \(\neq PY[0,1]\)Mid-period population -estimates exponential decline. ?Mid-period population -estimates exponential growth. ?periods get shorter, linear approximation gets betterCheck zooming point along population curve

heading: Method 3: Mean of starting and ending population counts
text:
Sometimes, don‚Äôt mid-period population \(N(T/2)\)long ‚Äôve collected data \(\geq\) 2 consecutive years, ‚Äôve got \(N(0)\) \(N(T)\)Like mid-period population, mean \(\left(N(0) + N(T)\right)/2\) also assumes linear growthBut doesn‚Äôt necessary equal mid-period populationRemember midpoint formula mid-point two points line?\[\left(x_m,y_m\right) = \left(\frac{x_1+x_2}{2},\frac{y_1+y_2}{2}\right)\]Draw line \(N(0)\) time \(0\) \(N(T)\) time \(T\).Plug populations \(N(t)\) \(x_i\) times \(0\) \(T\) \(y_i\)\[\left(N_m,t_m\right) = \left(\frac{N(0)+N(1)}{2},\frac{0+T}{2}\right)
                       = \left(\frac{N(0)+N(1)}{2},T/2\right)\]Mean population \(\left(N(0)+N(1)\right/2\) mid-points‚Äôs \(x\) coordinate

heading: Method 4: Mean of mid-interval population counts at evenly spaced intervals
text: Recall \(PY[0,T] = \sum_1^{P} N_i \times \Delta_i\)\(P\) equally spaced whole intervals, \(PY[0,T] = \sum_1^{P} N_i \times \Delta = \sum_1^{P} N_i \times \frac{1}{P}\)simply average per-interval population countsHigher resolution (.e., higher \(P\)) means better \(PY[0,T]\) approximationTo illustrate, let‚Äôs draw graphs average mid-interval estimates different resolutions.

human populations, demographic rates vary strongly age.age pattern mortality ages 0 90 9 countries 202016

heading: 2.1 Period age-specific rates
Crude rates as a function of age-specific rates and age structure
2.2 Age-standardization
text:
Population aging distorts crude death rate comparisonsQuestion: can eliminate effect age distribution?Answer: Age-standardized rates!Example: Assume 1933 instead 2019 age structure:23\[CDR^* = \sum_i M_i^{1933} \cdot C_i^{2019}\]Question: use 1933 standard? average \(C_i\) 1933 2019?Answer: choice 1933 2019 arbitrary, can largely impact comparison. Arguably better average across age distributions. careful one extreme age distribution isn‚Äôt skewing averageExample: standardized un-standardized CDRs women U.S. 1933 vs.¬†2019. CDR difference smaller older 2019 standard younger 1933 standard. Difference values mean 2019 1933 age structures. standardized differences much larger un-standardized difference.generally, standard population \(s\) focal population \(j\), age-standardized crude death rate (ASCDR):\[ASCDR^j = \sum_i M_i^{s} \cdot C_i^{j}\]
Even generally, rate \(R\) schedule age-specific rates \(R_i\):\[ASR^j = \sum_i R_i^{s} \cdot C_i^{j}\]

chapter: 3 Life tables and single decrement processes
heading: Death counts and population sizes from HMD
text: addition lifetables datasets, students using death counts annual population estimates. HMD uses following definitions students familiar :Deaths: Death counts collected finest level detail available. raw data aggregated, uniform methods used estimate death counts completed age (.e., age-last-birthday time death), calendar year death, calendar year birth. Death datasets following naming convention:Deaths_[length age interval years]_[length period years]Population size: Estimates population exposed risk death age-time interval based annual (January 1st) population estimates, small correction reflects timing deaths within interval. Death datasets following naming convention:‚ÄúPopulation‚Äù population estimates 1-year age intervals 1-year periods‚ÄúPopulation5‚Äù population estimates 5-year age intervals 1-year periods
